discussion.content:
Certainly sounds like A:
Server attestation refers to the process of authenticating and attesting to the state of a remote platform and its operating system. Attestation allows for changes in a remote host to be detected by authorized parties. This process allows administrators to validate server integrity and identify unauthorized changes.
It's A.

Maybe: C. vTPM ?
With an attached vTPM, a third party can remotely attest to (validate) the identity of the firmware and the guest operating system

Maybe: A. Centralized attestation server ?
HSM safeguards and manages digital keys. A centralized attestation server, ensures a platform is trustworthy by ensuring that there are no signs of security breaches in the system.

questions.question_text: A security architect has designated that a server segment of an enterprise network will require each server to have secure and measured boot capabilities. The architect now wishes to ensure service consumers and peers can verify the integrity of hosted services. Which of the following capabilities must the architect consider for enabling the verification?

discussion.content:
Maybe: chkconfig --level3 mysqld off ?
Instead of: chkconfig --level3 wpa_supplicant off ?
The question specifically states this host is not being used as a database server. 
I don't know what wpa_supplicant is.

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION -
As a security administrator, you are asked to harden a server running Red Hat Enterprise Server 5.5 64-bit.
This server is being used as a DNS and time server. It is not used as a database, web server, or print server. There are no wireless connections to the server, and it does not need to print.
The command window will be provided along with root access. You are connected via a secure shell with root access.
You may query help for a list of commands.
Instructions:
You need to disable and turn off unrelated services and processes.
It is possible to simulate a crash of your server session. The simulation can be reset, but the server cannot be rebooted.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.

discussion.content: Agree with D, the reason is the total cost overall even with the 2 incidents costing $1,000 a piece the total amount is $12,000 vs $15,000 for E which would have no incidents. Business wise that is the best decision. "Security" would have been B or E, but E would have been the best because it was cheaper. Thanks
Reviewing this, I think it is D. I believe the key word being business driven, means that it's purely down to the money. If it didn't include that, I'd go with E.

This is the type of dumb question comptia needs to remove from their exams. What does this have to do with our study material? Do you go with the business decision, basically what the question is asking, the D answer? Or do you go with the slightly more expensive option that has zero errors, which could potentially save you more down the road. It's a crap shoot really, until someone proves what the answer actually is.
Business is about MONEY. So D.

comments.content: Not entirely. Business is about customers. Allowing a virus instead of spending 1000 bucks could result in loss of business integrity, loss of customer, etc. still believe E is the correct answer.

I agree here. I find it unlikely and irresponsible to think that we would say "hey this product allows 2 incidents a year, and the other allows 0 incidents a year, but the first is a couple dollars cheaper so we should go with it." E is absolutely the answer here.

discussion.content:
I agree with answer E
It would NEVER be an acceptable business decision to say "We saved $1000, and anticipate we'll only get a virus or two a year." A company that makes decisions that way will go bankrupt pretty quickly. It's not an acceptable level of risk for a business to assume.

I'm not sure that I agree with D answer. According to several of my study guides. The risk assessment team must try to find a solution that provides the greatest risk reduction while maintaining the lowest cost. Consider that being a better business practice or best method for the risk assessment team to make their decision. With that E would be the right answer. Why.. because is minimizes the most risk at the cheapest price.
E. Product E - Lowest risk and lowest cost. You should never accept a product that sells failure...

comments.content: D. Its a business decision not a technical one. It would save the company 1k as opposed to E.

questions.question_text:
A government contracting company issues smartphones to employees to enable access to corporate resources. Several employees will need to travel to a foreign country for business purposes and will require access to their phones. However, the company recently received intelligence that its intellectual property is highly

desired by the same country's government. Which of the following MDM configurations would BEST reduce the risk of compromise while on foreign soil?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - Disable OTA updates
A is the answer

A
OTA Firmware updates will allow bluetooth or wifi rooting. Disable that business.
OTA updates is the way! Option A.
I'd go for A
C - Homomorphic encryption
literally the only one you guys got right...great job

Selected Answer: C
C. Homomorphic

"Homomorphic encryption is a big deal because it makes it possible to perform calculations on encrypted data. This means that data processing can be outsourced to a third party without the need to trust the third party to properly secure the data. Without the proper decryption key, the original data can’t be accessed.

This ability to perform processing on encrypted data has the potential to solve many major business challenges faced by companies across all industries."

https://www.keyfactor.com/blog/what-is-homomorphic-encryption/#:~:text=Homomorphic%20encryption%20algorithms%20are%20a,with%20a%20number%20of%20applications.

Selected Answer: C
clearly is C and the sky man explain why read below
It's C.

Agree with C being the answer: 
"In a nutshell, homomorphic encryption is a method of encryption that allows any data to remain encrypted while it’s being processed and manipulated. It enables you or a third party (such as a cloud provider) to apply functions on encrypted data without needing to reveal the values of the data."
https://www.thesslstore.com/blog/what-is-homomorphic-encryption/

questions.question_text: A financial institution would like to store its customer data in a cloud but still allow the data to be accessed and manipulated while encrypted. Doing so would prevent the cloud service provider from being able to decipher the data due to its sensitivity. The financial institution is not concerned about computational overheads and slow speeds. Which of the following cryptographic techniques would BEST meet the requirement?
